r:Content.xhtml:div: This is an example DDI 3.1 File based on the Labour Force Survey administered by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The original form is available under a Creative Commons licence and can be found online as an Information Paper on the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

d:LiteralText.d:Text: What was your age at your last birthday?
Are you a usual resident of this personal residence?
What is the person's present marital status?
S.D. ONLY
What is the postcode of the suburb or town where you usually live?
In which country were you born?
In what year did you first arrive in Australia to live here for one year or more?
Are you of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander origin?(For persons of both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander origin, mark both 'Yes' boxes.)
Sequence Guide
Are you still at school?
DATE LEFT SCHOOL
Are you currently studying at a school, TAFE college, university or other educational institution as a full-time student?
Are you permanently unable to work?
Are you permanently not intending to work?
Last week did you do any work at all in a job, business or farm?
Last week, did you do any work without pay in a family business?
Did you have a job, business or farm that you were away from because of holidays, sickness or any other reason?
AT ANY TIME DURING THE LAST 4 WEEKS HAS ..... BEEN LOOKING FOR FULL-TIME WORK?
HAS ..... BEEN LOOKING FOR PART-TIME WORK AT ANY TIME DURING THE LAST 4 WEEKS?
(YOU TOLD ME THAT ..... DIDN’T LOOK FOR WORK DURING THE LAST 4 WEEKS.) WAS THAT BECAUSE ..... WAS WAITING TO START WORK ..... HAD ALREADY OBTAINED?
DID ..... HAVE MORE THAN 1 JOB OR BUSINESS LAST WEEK?
WAS THAT BECAUSE ..... CHANGED JOBS DURING THE WEEK?
THE NEXT FEW QUESTIONS ARE ABOUT THE WORK ..... DOES NOW.
THE NEXT FEW QUESTIONS ARE ABOUT THE JOB OR BUSINESS IN WHICH ..... USUALLY WORKS THE MOST HOURS, THAT IS, ..... MAIN JOB.
DID ..... WORK FOR AN EMPLOYER, OR IN ..... OWN BUSINESS?
IS ..... PAID A WAGE OR SALARY, OR SOME OTHER FORM OF PAYMENT?
WHAT ARE ..... (WORKING/PAYMENT) ARRANGEMENTS?
DOES ..... HAVE EMPLOYEES (IN THAT BUSINESS)?
IS THAT BUSINESS INCORPORATED?
I WOULD NOW LIKE TO ASK ABOUT WHEN ..... WORKED (IN ..... MAIN JOB) LAST WEEK. [REMEMBERING THAT (Day) WAS A PUBLIC HOLIDAY,] DID ..... WORK (IN THAT JOB) ON MON TUES WED THU FRI SAT SUN?
Sequence Guide
ON THE DAYS THAT ..... WORKED (IN THAT JOB), DID ..... HAVE ANY TIME OFF?
DID ..... WORK ANY EXTRA HOURS OR OVERTIME?
Sequence Guide
HOW MANY HOURS DID ..... ACTUALLY WORK IN ..... MAIN JOB LAST WEEK (LESS THE TIME OFF) (BUT) (COUNTING THE EXTRA HOURS WORKED)?
HOW MANY HOURS DID ..... ACTUALLY WORK (IN ALL ..... JOBS) LAST WEEK (LESS THE TIME OFF) (BUT) (COUNTING THE EXTRA HOURS WORKED)?
HOW MANY HOURS DOES ..... USUALLY WORK EACH WEEK IN (THAT JOB/THAT BUSINESS/ALL ..... JOBS)?
Goto Q.65
HOW MANY HOURS DOES ..... USUALLY WORK EACH WEEK IN (THAT JOB/THAT BUSINESS/ALL ..... JOBS)?
WHAT WAS THE MAIN REASON ..... WORKED LESS THAN 35 HOURS LAST WEEK?
Goto Q.65
DID ..... HAVE MORE THAN 1 JOB OR BUSINESS LAST WEEK?
THE NEXT FEW QUESTIONS ARE ABOUT THE JOB OR BUSINESS IN WHICH ..... USUALLY WORKS THE MOST HOURS.
DOES ..... WORK FOR AN EMPLOYER, OR IN ..... OWN BUSINESS?
IS ..... PAID A WAGE OR SALARY, OR SOME OTHER FORM OF PAYMENT?
WHAT ARE ..... (WORKING/PAYMENT) ARRANGEMENTS?
DOES ..... HAVE EMPLOYEES (IN THAT BUSINESS)?
IS THAT BUSINESS INCORPORATED?
WHAT WAS THE MAIN REASON ..... WAS AWAY FROM WORK LAST WEEK?
WAS ..... ON WORKERS’ COMPENSATION LAST WEEK?
WILL ..... BE RETURNING TO WORK FOR ..... EMPLOYER?
UP UNTIL THE END OF LAST WEEK, HOW LONG HAD ..... BEEN AWAY FROM WORK?
WAS ..... PAID, OR WILL ..... BE PAID, FOR ANY PART OF THE LAST 4 WEEKS?
WHAT WAS THE MAIN REASON ..... WAS AWAY FROM WORK LAST WEEK?
HOW MANY HOURS DOES ..... USUALLY WORK EACH WEEK IN (THAT JOB/THAT BUSINESS/ALL ..... JOBS)?
WOULD ..... PREFER TO WORK MORE HOURS THAN ..... USUALLY WORKS?
LASTWEEK, WAS ..... AVAILABLE TO WORK MORE HOURS THAN ..... USUALLY WORKS?
IN THE NEXT 4 WEEKS, WOULD ..... BE AVAILABLE TO WORK MORE HOURS THAN ..... USUALLY WORKS?
IN THE LAST 4 WEEHAS ..... you DONE ANYTHING TO OBTAIN MORE HOURS OF WORK?
DOES ..... WANT TO WORK 35 HOURS OR MORE A WEEK?
AT ANY TIME IN THE LAST 4 WEHAS ..... you DONE STUFF TO GET MORE HOURS?
WHAT (WAS/IS) ..... OCCUPATION IN (THAT/..... MAIN) (JOB/BUSINESS)?
WHAT KIND OF BUSINESS OR SERVICE IS CARRIED OUT BY ..... (EMPLOYER AT THE PLACE WHERE ..... WORKS/BUSINESS)?
WHAT IS THE NAME OF ..... (EMPLOYER/BUSINESS)?
THAS ..... you WORKED (FOR ..... EMPLOYER/IN ..... BUSINESS) FOR 12 MONTHS OR MORE?
HOW MANY MONHAS ..... you WORKED (FOR ..... EMPLOYER/IN ..... BUSINESS)?
DOES ..... EXPECT TO BE WORKING (FOR ..... EMPLOYER/IN ..... BUSINESS) IN 12 MONTHS TIME?
WHAT IS THE MAIN REASON ..... (EXPECTS TO/MAY) FINISH WORK (FOR ..... EMPLOYER/IN ..... BUSINESS) IN THE NEXT 12 MONTHS?
AT ANY TIME DURING THE LAST 4 WEHAS ..... you BEEN LOOKING FOR FULL-TIME WORK?
HAS ..... you BEEN LOOKING FOR PART-TIME WORK AT ANY TIME DURING THE LAST 4 WEEKS?
AT ANY TIME IN THE LAST 4 WEHAS ..... you DONE STUFF TO FIND A JOB?
IF ..... HAD FOUND A (PART-TIME) JOB COULD ..... HAVE STARTED WORK LAST WEEK?
WHAT WERE THE REASONS ..... COULD NOT HAVE STARTED WORK LAST WEEK?
WILL ..... BE STARTING THAT WORK IN THE NEXT 4 WEEKS?
COULD ..... START IN THE NEXT 4 WEEKS IF WORK WAS AVAILABLE?
(YOU TOLD ME THAT ..... DIDN’T LOOK FOR WORK DURING THE LAST 4 WEEKS.) WAS THAT BEC ..... WAS WAS WAITING TO START (PAID) WORK ..... HAD ALREADY OBTAINED?
WEEK, WAS WAS ..... WAITING TO START (PAID) WORK ..... HAD ALREADY OBTAINED?
WILL ..... BE STARTING THAT WORK IN THE NEXT 4 WEEKS?
COULD ..... HAVE STARTED LAST WEEK IF THAT WORK HAD BEEN AVAILABLE?
WILL THAT WORK BE FULL-TIME?
WHEN DID ..... BEGIN LOOKING FOR WORK?
WHEN DID ..... LAST WORK FOR 2 WEEKS OR MORE?
Sequence Guide
WHAT WAS ..... OCCUPATION IN THAT JOB OR BUSINESS?
WHAT KIND OF BUSINESS OR SERVICE WAS CARRIED OUT BY ..... EMPLOYER OR BUSINESS AT THE PLACE WHERE ..... WORKED?
WHAT WAS THE NAME OF ..... EMPLOYER OR BUSINESS?
WHAT WAS THE MAIN REASON ..... STOPPED WORKING IN ..... JOB OR BUSINESS?
DID ..... USUALLY WORK 35 HOURS OR MORE A WEEK IN ..... JOB OR BUSINESS?
WHEN DID ..... LAST WORK FOR AT LEAST 2 WEEKS IN A JOB OF 35 HOURS OR MORE A WEEK?
I would like to ask about last week, that is, the week starting Monday the .... and ending (last Sunday the ... / Yesterday).

d:Sequence.r:Label: Standard Labour Force Underemployment Question Block
Standard Labour Force Employment Absence Question Block
Standard Labour Force Underemployment Question Block
Standard Labour Force Labour Segment Identification Question Block
d:Sequence.r:Description: Filter questions to identify those most likely to be employed (people who respond 'yes' to questions 19–21), to identify those most likely to be unemployed (people who answer 'yes' to questions 22–24), and to determine the majority of persons not in the labour force.

d:Sequence.r:Label: Standard Labour Force Unemployment Question Block
d:Sequence.r:Description: Identify unemployed persons and obtain information on unemployment related characteristics, including duration of unemployment, occupation and industry of last job, and reasons for leaving last job.

d:Sequence.r:Label: Standard Labour Force Survey Main Question Block

d:LiteralText.d:Text: Read statement for the first person to be interviewed in the household, or if the respondent changes.

r:Description.xhtml:p: The attached questionnaire is used for the February, May, August and November surveys. For the remaining months of the year a slightly modified questionnaire is used which excludes questions collecting information about underemployment, occupation and industry, job tenure, and last job details for unemployed persons: that is, questions 60 to 72 and questions 88 to 91.

The LFS questionnaire may appear formidable if simply read through from beginning to end. However, in practice, only a subset of the questions are asked of each person. Interviewers follow the sequencing of the questionnaire to ensure that only questions appropriate to each person's labour force experience are asked during the interview. In the months where there are supplementary survey questions attached to the main labour force questionnaire, respondents are sequenced to question 94, as shown on the atttached questionnaire, when all of the appropriate labour force questions have been asked.

xhtml:p.xhtml:strong: This is an example DDI 3.1 File based on the Labour Force Survey administered by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The original form is available under a Creative Commons licence and can be found online as an Information Paper on the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

l:Category.r:Label: Yes - Usual Resident of Personal Dwelling
No - This is a Special Dwelling

g:Purpose.r:Content: Introduction 1. Sex is a basic demographic variable used almost universally in statistical and administrative data collections relating to people. It differentiates any population in terms of male and female numbers and characteristics. The meaning, description and use of this concept is generally standard and consistent across Australian data sources. There have been and continue to be some variations in the name used for the concept ('gender' instead of 'sex') and in labels for and ordering of categories. For example 'Women' and 'Men' or 'Boys' and 'Girls' may be used instead of 'Males' and 'Females'. 2. This standard seeks to achieve consistency across all data sources in terminology, data collection procedures and definitions of categories associated with human sexes, and to achieve clarity with respect to the small number of cases where a person's sex cannot be categorised as Male or Female or may change over time.

l:LogicalProduct.r:Label: ABS Classification of Sex
l:LogicalProduct.r:Description:
Classification and Coding
The classification criteria 8. Physical biology is the criterion used to classify persons into the categories 'male' and 'female'. This criterion is physical rather than genetic to cover the exceptional cases such as sex change operations. In the vast majority of cases the physical and genetic categories are identical.
The standard classification 9. Sex is a flat classification having only one level with the two categories 'Male' and 'Female'. 10. In some situations there may be a need for the additional category 'Intersex or Indeterminate'. This refers to a person, who because of a genetic condition, was born with reproductive organs or sex chromosomes that are not exclusively male or female (for whatever reason).
The code structure 11. The code structure is simply:
1 Male 2 Female
12. If it is necessary to include the category 'Intersex or Indeterminate', it should be allocated the code '3'.
Residual categories and codes 13. Not applicable.
Supplementary codes 14. The following supplementary code is used to code inadequately described responses and non-responses: 0 Not stated/Inadequately described
Scope of the variable 15. The variable Sex applies to all persons.
Application of the classification to other variables 16. The Sex classification is not applicable to any other variable.

l:Category.r:Label: Male
l:Category.r:Description: 'Male' is a universally accepted term used to indicate the biological characteristics of a person. Enumeration to this category is either inferred by the interviewer or accepted as reported by the respondent.

l:Category.r:Label: Female
l:Category.r:Description: 'Female' is a universally accepted term used to indicate the biological characteristics of a person. Enumeration to this category is either inferred by the interviewer or accepted as reported by the respondent.

l:Category.r:Label: Intersex or Indeterminate
l:Category.r:Description: This category is used when it is not possible for sex to be determined. It is used in surveys which include, for example, perinatal collections and hospital morbidity.

c:Concept.r:Description: 'Female' is a universally accepted term used to indicate the biological characteristics of a person.
Gender, as defined by Stoller, is "the amount of masculinity or femininity found in a person".
This category is used when it is not possible for sex to be determined. It is used in surveys which include, for example, perinatal collections and hospital morbidity.
'Male' is a universally accepted term used to indicate the biological characteristics of a person.
Sex is defined as the biological difference between male and female.

d:QuestionScheme.r:Label: ABS/PSG Sex Collection
d:QuestionScheme.r:Description:
Standard question module 17. For the collection of data on sex the ABS standard questionnaire module is a tick box question as shown below. Due to tradition in the ABS and other collections, the category Male is shown first.
Sex: q Male q Female
18. Depending on the collection methodology and number of people each form covers, the introductory question or statement may need to vary slightly. For example, a slight variation may need to be made to the standard question for self enumerated collections. The standard question set for a self enumerated questionnaire which collects data for more than one person is as follows:
Sex: Mark one box for each person.
Person 1 q Male q Female
Person 2 q Male q Female
Person 3 (etc.)
It may be offensive to ask the sex of the respondent
19. When collecting data on sex by personal interview, asking the sex of the respondent or other household members is usually unnecessary and may be inappropriate, or even offensive. It is usually a simple matter to infer the sex of the respondent or household member from other cues such as observation, relationship to respondent, or first name. If this is not possible, the interviewer should ask for each person not present at the interview, whether the person is male or female. 20. Category 3, 'Intersex or Indeterminate' should not generally be used on data collection forms completed by the respondent. It should only be used if the person or respondent volunteers that the person is intersex or where it otherwise becomes clear during the collection process that the individual is neither male nor female. Indeterminate is normally used for babies for whom sex has not been determined for whatever reason.

d:LiteralText.d:Text: Sex:
